docs.lead_paragraph: This story has a chance of ending happily. But it begins last fall in a mangy downtown apartment as Katy Yeager, seven months pregnant, stares at a syringe and the crumpled foil that holds $40 worth of heroin.

headline.main: Special Report: In the Heart of U.S. Opioid Epidemic, Help Finds Mother and Baby
headline.print_headline: Special Report: In the Heart of U.S. Opioid Epidemic, Help Finds Mother and Baby

docs.lead_paragraph: Reporter Duff Wilson reviewed more than 50,000 pages of documents and interviewed more than 300 people to assess the impact of opioids on newborns. The documents included about 5,800 child fatality reports and tens of thousands of additional pages of medical records and other documents obtained through more than 200 public records requests. To obtain those documents, Reuters began filing Freedom of Information Act requests in 2014 with federal, state, county and city agencies.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two days after giving birth in the summer of 2014, Reanne Pederson left a hospital with her baby boy Avery and a prescription for 20 hydrocodone pills to treat pain.

docs.lead_paragraph: Brayden Cummings turned 6 weeks old the morning his mother suffocated him.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Congress adopted the Keeping Children and Families Safe Act in 2003, the intent – spelled out in the law – was to ensure protection for drug-dependent newborns, not to punish mothers battling addiction.

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Institutes of Health is launching a new project to help unravel how early-in-life environmental exposures may affect autism, obesity and certain other childhood disorders. It's a second shot at tackling those important questions, after a more ambitious research attempt failed.

headline.main: NIH Takes Another Shot at Studying Environment, Child Health
headline.print_headline: NIH Takes Another Shot at Studying Environment, Child Health

docs.lead_paragraph: Kim Kardashian wants a million-dollar necklace as a “push present” for giving birth to her second baby. At that rate, few of us could afford families.
